column4: So nobody's got any thoughts on my swap size issue, where the swap partition size reported by swapon -s is less than the size of the swap partition I created?
what's your problem?
paste the outputs of the commands you used

I installed a system with a large partition, encryption on that, lvm on the encryption, an 8400000kb swap volume in the lvm, and the rest root in the lvm. My swap came out, after boot, to about 8200000kb, which prevents me from hibernating because that's smaller than my RAM. I'm trying to figure out the easiest way to fix this.
I didn't use particular commands, I used the alternate installer in manual partitioning mode.
who told you that to hybernate you need the swap to be the size of the RAM?
Someone here, though I'd assumed that before being told. Hibernate saves RAM to swap, right? So if swap's too small, where does the RAM go?
my guess is hibernation is not like ghosting the RAM, it will take the used bits and save it in disk so the swap could be much less
I don't think that is the reason, not for 200M difference of course
I will reboot now and be back to discuss this more
thanks.
